dc:description:
The relationship between MT-ATP6 and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of May 24, 2021. The MT-ATP6 gene encodes the ATP synthase (complex V) subunit 6. Defects of this protein lead to complex V deficiency.

The MT-ATP6 gene was first reported in relation to maternally inherited Leigh syndrome spectrum in 1992 (PMID: 1550128). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included 6 variants in 18 cases (2 with m.8851T>C, 1 with m.8993T>C, 9 with m.8993T>G, 4 with m.9176T>C, 1 with m.9185T>C, and 1 with m.9191T>C) from 12 publications (PMIDs: 9270604, 11245730, 17352390, 8554662, 9501263, 23206802, 7603783, 16217706, 1456751, 1550128, 7668837, 10604142). Of note, while Gene Curation SOP Version 8 maxes case level missense variant total score at 7, the Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel agreed the maximum score would be 12 given that the majority of pathogenic mitochondrial DNA variants are missense variants. Variants in the MT-ATP6 gene are associated with other mitochondrial phenotypes, including Neurogenic muscle weakness, ataxia and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP), axonal Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and spinocerebellar ataxia (PMID: 30763462). Segregation information is scored as case level evidence according to the criteria established by the Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel. Loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by known protein interaction, expression, functional alterations in patient cells, rescue in human cells, and animal models (PMIDs: 27977873, 25613900, 19160410, 18256697, 24316278, 17855363). 

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support this gene-disease relationship, including that more than three years have elapsed from the first proposal of the association. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on May 24, 2021 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: 1 point for mitochondrial dysfunction in yeast.

Mutant had slow growth on respiratory substrates, attributed to a major lowering in the mitochondrial ATP synthesis rate, by about 90% compared with wild type.  Oxygen consumption
rate in the NARP mutant was also compromised, by about 80%, due to a decreased complex IV content.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast (m.8993T>G)

evidence.dc:description: 1 point for mitochondrial dysfunction in animal model
decreased ATP production
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast

evidence.dc:description: Rescued mitochondrial dysfunction (1 point)

Cybrids infected with adenovirus leads to selective reduction of mutant mtDNA; results in cells with 
significantly increased rates of oxygen consumption and ATP production
evidence.rdfs:label: Selective elimination of mutant mitochondrial genomes

evidence.dc:description: Cybrid study showing decreased ATP synthesis, that also correlates with mutant load

ATP production: REDUCED: significantly (P <0.001) reduced in all clones when these were compared
with Rho-zero control cell lines.

ATP synthesis correlating with mutation load:  L156R and L217R mutated clones showed an ATP production that decreased as the percentage of mutated DNA increased. This reduction reached
significance (P <0.01) at 50% mutation load with the L156R mutation and at 84% mutation load with the L217R mutation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cybrids - p.L156R, L217R, L156P, L217P

evidence.dc:description: Shares a function/interacts with one other gene product (ATP5MD aka USMG5)
Complex V subunits
evidence.rdfs:label: Complex V subunit

evidence.dc:description: expressed in brain, highest expression in basal ganglia
https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000198899-MT-ATP6/brain
evidence.rdfs:label: expressed in brain - highest in BG

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Onset: 5.5 years

Plasma lactate: 1.8
CSF lactate: 6.3
Brain MRI: LS

m.8993T>C:
94+-1% in several tissues in proband
brother with ataxia and ID/DD with 92+-2% het in several tissues

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 (extensively tested in maternal family members and tracks) + 0.5 for known path

evidence.rdfs:label: Index case (IV-1)
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
In first 3 months of life, feed poorly and slowly, weight fell from the 70th to 25th percentile, hypotonia and head lag.

Elevated blood lactate (3-5 mM )

Brain MRI: Bilateral symmetrical basal ganglia abnormalities consistent with Leigh disease. 
Visual and auditory evoked potentials, EEG were normal.

6 months: increasing lethargy, an episode of apnea, and seizure activity thought to be caused by otitis media. Further apneic episodes occurred in the following weeks, and after discussion with the parents resuscitative support was withdrawn and the patient died of respiratory failure.


Autopsy (7 months): bilateral cystic lesions of the basal ganglia, thalamus, periventricular region, substantia nigra, and tectal and tegmental brain stem; proliferation of astrocytes and blood vessels in cystic areas

Proband het levels (m;8993T>G):
Het: FCL: "very high"; >95%
Brain:  >95%
Kidney:  >95%
Liver:  >95%

mother (FCL het: 71%; lymphoblast culture: 39%) 
grandmother (II-1; FCL het: 52%; lymphoblast het: 45%) 
affected maternal aunt (Lymphoblast culture:  >95%)
less severely affected maternal uncle: FCL het:78%;  lymphoblast culture: 79%

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for variant segregating with family member affected status; 0.5 for known pathogenic variant

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
9 months: febrile illness: coma, periodic breathing, seizures and pyramidal signs
severe metabolic acidosis (BE [9.9 mmol/L; HCO 11.2 mmol/L) 
Elevated blood and CSF lactate 7mmol/L (normal \2). 
Brain CT: symmetric hypodensities in the basal ganglia and brainstem (Figure 1)
Died 3 weeks after hospitalization from cardiorespiratory arrest

m.9176T>C present at >95% in muscle and fibroblasts from proband
Mother (healthy) lymphocytes: 50%
maternal uncle (healthy) lymphocytes: 70%
MGM (healthy) lymphocytesL 10%

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for segregation and 0.5 for known pathogenic variant

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Currently a 6-year-old boy , referred at age 16 months for developmental delay. 

Development normal until 4 months when noted could not roll over.

By 3 years, nonverbal and not walking.

Brain MRI: bilateral T1 and T2 signal increases involving the putamen and the periaqueductal region. 

Elevated plasma lactate - 0.98 mmol/L (range, 0.30-0.80 mmol/L). 
Elevated CSF lactate - 3.8 mmol/L; range, 0.9-2.8 mmol/L.

At age 6 years, cruising, single words; stable for several years

m.9176T>C: essential homoplasmic in muscle, fibroblasts, leukocytes;
Affected brother leukocytes: 98%.
Healthy mother leukocytes: 7%;
Healthy brotherleukocytes: 55%;
Healthy sister: 76%

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 points for segregation; 0.5 for known pathogenic variant

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Generally healthy boy until 3 years old:
URI - became ataxic then recovered; normal brain CT and EEG

4 years old:
Febrile illness, became progressively lethargic, developed metabolic acidosis and recurrent apnea; neuro exam revealed lethargic/motionless, diffuse hypotonia, areflexia, bilateral Babinski sign

Deteriorated, ventilator-dependent, lost brainstem reflex activities; had repeated episodes of apnea, and died 1 month after admission.

Mildly elevated blood and CSF lactate. 

Brain CT: symmetrical hypodensities iin basal ganglia and, later, also the periventricular and periaqueductal areas, the internal capsule, and the brain peduncles. 

Brain MRI: bilateral T1 and T2 signal increases involving the basal ganglia, thalamus, periaqueductal and periventricular regions, and posterior cords of medulla. 

Muscle biopsy: mild nonspecific atrophy of both type I and type II fibers, no RRF, normla SDH and COX stain; normal RC activities

Autopsy: characteristic findings of LS - bilateral cystic lesions in basal ganglia, thalamus,  periventricular region, substantia nigra, and tectal and tegmental brainstem. Loss of Purkinje
cells was marked in the cerebellum.

22 year old mother with DD/ID, lifelong ataxia/unsteady gait; brain MRI showed mild cerebellar atrophy.

All other family members were  healthy


m.9176T>C virtually homoplasmic in proband muscle
mother: 93% in WBCs
maternal uncle: 88% in WBCs
MGM: 76% in WBCs
MGM's sister: 15% in WBCs

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for known path variant; 0.5 for segregation

evidence.rdfs:label: Case
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
7yo girl with hypotonia, psychomotor regression, choreoathetosis, lactic acidosis, and symmetrical low-density areas in the basal ganglia on CT. 

Muscle biopsy showed no RRF but COX activity was diffusely decreased.

Found to harbor m.8993T>G - 56.6% in the patient’s blood cells and 4.8% in mother’s.

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for known pathogenic variant; 0.5 for segregation

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 3; Individual IV:2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
LS on CT scan and autopsy; onset 6 months
CSF lactate: 3.1; 5.4
Plasma lactate: 2.0 to 5.6

m.8993T>G: 99% in proband (in 3+ tissues)
mother: 0% in blood
Although appears de novo, maternal family history of several individuals with unexplained infant death

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for segregation and 0.5 for known pathogenic variant

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient IV/3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
LS on neuropathology

Hypotonic after birth; delayed development.

At 6 months old had extension fits and apneic spells; died of respiratory failure at 7 months old

m.8993T>G heteroplasmy: 98% in muscle
Brother severely affected and has 92% in muscle
Healthy sister with 41% in leukocytes
Mother with poor vision ant 54% in leukocytes
Other family members testing and heteroplasmy tracks Figure 1)

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for segregation

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Normal neonatal period and development until 4 months old - weakness of the neck muscles and axial hypotonia noticed. 

6 months: became less responsive, increasingly fatigued, and had episodes of hyperventilation.

8 months: metabolic acidosis with increased lactate levels, between 2.8 and 4.7 mmol/L in blood and up to 5.0 mmol/L in CSF. 

Brain CT: decreased attenuation of the basal ganglia, thalami, and mesencephalon. 

18 months: severe psychomotor retardation with a developmental age around 5 months, muscular
weakness and hypotonia and discrete choreathetosis.

Died at 28 months of age.

m.9191T>C: 90% FCL, 94% muscle in proband.
No detectable levels of variant in mother or healthy siblings.

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for known pathogenic variant

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 9; Individual II-1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Onset 3 months

CT: LS, periventricular leukomalacia
CSF lactate: 5.6
Plasma lactate: 5.8
Autopsy: LS

m.8993T>G homoplasmic in blood, no other tissues tested
mother not tested

evidence.dc:description:
0.5 for variant segregating with disease manifestations in family
2 homoplasmic occurrences in gnomAD; 3 in genbank; 10 in helix

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report - girl
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
5th child of nonconsanguineous Roma parents

This girl was healthy until 8 months old when hypotonia and loss of responsive smiling were observed. 

After 1 year old: had developmental delay (on 7-month-old level)

14 months: weight, HC <3rd percentile
Neuro exam: central hypotonia, ataxia, and a poor hearing response. 

Brain MRI: diffuse symmetric hyperintensity on a T2-weighted image of the bilateral basal ganglia, including the caudate nuclei. 
The white matter, brainstem, and spinal cord did not show any abnormalities. 

mild metabolic acidosis with a base excess of −4 mmol/L (reference range ±2 mmol/L)
elevated blood lactate level of 2.7 mmol/L (reference range 0.5–2.2 mmol/L)
elevated CSF lactate level of 3.8–6.4 mmol/L (reference range 1.2–2.1 mmol/L) without hyperlactaciduria. 
Gas chromatography mass spectrometry showed elevated ethyl malonate in her urine (22 mg/g of
creatinine; reference range b15 mg/g). 
Amino acid profiles in the CSF and urine were normal, but an elevated alanine blood level of 649 μmol/L (reference range 150–500 μmol/L) was observed.
 
Muscle biopsy: normal histology
Enzyme histochemistry:  focal subsarcolemmal accumulation of SDH reaction product in up to 5% of muscle fibers (Fig. 1); COX-negative fibers were not observed.
EM: focal increase of subsarcolemmal mitochondria without altered morphology.
OXPHOS: diminished OXPHOS activity due to a disturbed complex V.
RC enzyme activities:  normal to increased activities of respiratory chain complexes I, II, III, I+III, II+III, and IV and citrate synthase (CS) in comparison to age-related controls (for details see
supplementary Table 1).
Muscle BN-PAGE: marked decrease of the steady state level of complex V and the accumulation of its disintegrated parts were found (Fig. 2A). 

Skin fibroblasts:
BN-PAGE, Western blot: mild decrease (80% of controls) in complex V. However, free F1-part and free F1-alpha subunits were not observed (Fig. 2B). 

Muscle mtDNA sequencing: T-to-C transition at position 8851 in the MTATP6 gene; heteroplasmic:
muscle (97%)
hair follicles (95%)
blood (92%)
buccal cells (92%) 
urinary sediment cells (87%)

Mother with CMT phenotype: Heteroplasmy:
buccal cells (85%)
hair follicles (96%)
blood (68%)
urinary sediment cells (69%)

Healthy sister:
Heteroplasmy:
60% - blood 
52% - buccal cells

evidence.dc:description:
0.5 for segregation with disease (lower heterplasmy in healthy mother)
2 homoplasmic occurrences in gnomAD; 3 in genbank; 10 in helix

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
2.5 yo boy admitted for developmental delay. 
Normal development in first year of life.
Walked at 18 months but fell frequently, speech delay, hypotonia, was (at 2.5 years) unable to walk without falling, had intermittent choreoathetotic movements of trunk and limbs increased in the resting position and decreased with voluntary movements.

Normal blood lactate; elevated CSF lactate  (2.7 mmol/L; normal 2.2) 

Muscle bx was normal. 

Cranial MRI (Fig I): lesions in the basal ganglia consisting of a prolongation of both T1- and T2-weighted signals in the caudate nucleus and putamen, while the midbrain and brainstem were normal.

m.8851T>C
Proband was virtually homoplasmic in leukocytes and fibroblasts.
Mother's blood was 85%
MGM had undetectable levels of the variant

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for variant segregating with disease in family; 0.5 for known pathogenic variant

evidence.rdfs:label: III-7
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
8½-year-old boy at the time of publication
Well and intellectually normal; presented with a 3-month history of frequent falls while walking, ataxia, lassitude, slowed speech, and poor concentration. 
Deterioration during a febrile illness attributed to streptococcal pharyngitis brought him to medical attention. 

Mild quadriceps weakness and ataxia, bilateral pes cavus, absent ankle jerks

Weakness and ataxia temporarily improved 

Presented again 3 months later with intellectual decline and increased weakness. 
Exam showed saccadic paresis most prominent in vertical gaze, and fine pendular and
rotatory nystagmus, bilateral intermittent ptosis and bilateral facial weakness; no
ophthalmoplegia or optic atrophy
Intermittent choreiform movements of the face were noted.

He rapidly deteriorated into a comatose state, required assisted ventilation due to brain stem
dysfunction, and died within 2 weeks of this admission.

Normal venous lactate (1.41, 1.90 mmol/l)
Elevated CSF lactate of 3.68 mmol/l (normal <2 mmol/l). 

WPW on EKG

Brain MRI showed symmetrical hyperintense signals in the putamina, caudate bodies and periaqueductal gray matter on T2-weighted images (Fig. 1A) with prominent involvement of the cortical cerebellar cortex. 

ETC in muscle and skin

m.9185T>C:
This proband had 90% heteroplasmy
"All the affected children (III-4, III-5, III-7, III-8) showed>90% heteroplasmy for the 9,185T>C
mtDNA mutation. The mother of the proband (II-6) showed 86% and the asymptomatic mother (II-5) of III-5 showed 81%. The affected uncle (II-4) was 85% heteroplasmic (not shown) while the asymptomatic maternal grandmother was 52% heteroplasmic and the asymptomatic brother of the proband (III-6) was 17%."

evidence.rdfs:label: IV-1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
10-year-old girl at time of report

Normal motor and intellectual development during first year of life

22 months: onset of drug-resistant epileptic seizures; able to pronounce only a few words and showed ataxic-spastic gait.

Brain MRI revealed bilateral hyperlucencies in T2-weighted images in the putamen and periventricular areas.

6 years: several episodes of coma during febrile illnesses. 
Following last episode, unable to control her head and irreversibly lost all intellectual
performance. 

Elevated venous blood lactate levels (3.1 mmol/L, normal ,2) 

Neuro exam:  alert child who could not walk unaided and had dystonic postures. 

Funduscopy showed bilaterally pale optic disks but excluded pigmentary changes of the retina. Nerve conduction velocities showed an axonal sensory-motor polyneuropathy.

SISTER with neuropath features of LS (IV-2)

m.9176T>C:
>95% het in proband and sister with LS (muscle, blood, and skin fibroblasts from IV-1 and in all postmortem tissues studied from IV-2)
-Rest of family members had heteroplasmy levels corresponding to affected status (Figure 1A)

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 for known pathogenic variant; 0.5 for segregation

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 4; Individual IV:1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Onset 3 days

First brain CT normal; second showed LS
CSF lactate: 4.7
Plasma lactate: 4.4, 4.5
Autopsy consistent with LS

m.8993T>G heteroplasmy levels:
Proband: 90% +- 6% (tested in multiple tissues)
healthy mother: blood and fibroblasts 51%
healthy MGM: blood 17%
healthy MGM's mother: blood 0%
healthy MGM's sister's daughter: blood 0%
brother with unexplained infant death - 89% in multiple tissues
brother with MR/DD: blood 89%, fibroblasts 91%
